author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Molli and Max in the Future’ Review: Love, Interplanetary Style
description: This rom-com brings futuristic absurdity and nimble timing to a comfort-food story line of friends turned soul mates.
content: Science fiction has become such a mainstay of lumbering franchises that it’s hard not to root for left-field small-scale twists on the genre like the fizzy, funny “Molli and Max in the Future.” Michael Lukk Litwak’s quantum-age rom-com brings futuristic absurdity and nimble timing to a tried-and-true story line of friends turned soul mates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City’s Housing Crunch Is the Worst It Has Been in Over 50 Years
description: Only 1.4 percent of the city’s rentals were available in 2023, according to new data, the lowest portion since 1968. The market was even tighter for lower-cost apartments.
content: New York City’s housing crunch is the worst it has been in more than 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: unilaterally
description: This word has appeared in 215 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word unilaterally has appeared in 215 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 15 in “New York City Is Offering Free Online Therapy to Teens: Will It Work?” by Ellen Barry and Christina Caron:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Why the Cost of Biden’s Climate Law Keeps Going Up
description: Forecasters say the president’s clean-energy incentives will be more effective than they had originally expected, in part because of new federal regulations.
content: The estimated price tag for President Biden’s clean-energy and climate agenda has effectively doubled since the Inflation Reduction Act was signed into law a year and a half ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Hot Takes and Walking Ads Fuel Super Bowl’s Radio Row
description: During Super Bowl week, current and former athletes help companies hawk their wares on radio stations and podcasts. “It is a phenomenal quid pro quo,” one host said.
content: Chad Johnson said that the winning coach in the Super Bowl would be showered with red Gatorade. He predicted that wide receiver Kadarius Toney, who has not played in the Kansas City Chiefs’ three playoff games, would score the first touchdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Will You Be Watching Super Bowl LVIII?
description: Which stories — whether about the players, the coaches, the commercials or a certain pop star — have your attention this year?
content: Are you a football fan? Will you be watching the Super Bowl this Sunday?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy and Emma Goldberg
title: Navigating Israel’s War When One Spouse Is Jewish, and One Is Not.
description: For some couples, figuring out how to talk about the war in Gaza is a hurdle in the relationship, but ultimately one that has brought them closer.
content: When Ava Friedmann and Michael Henein were married, they used a tablecloth from Ms. Friedmann’s grandmother as a huppah, or ritual canopy held above the couple in a Jewish wedding. Mr. Henein’s father, who is a Coptic Christian from Egypt, anointed them with holy oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: I Can Cook Myself Cauliflowers
description: Cauliflower chaat and gochujang buttered noodles are good, golden single suppers.
content: Romance is in the eye of the beholder. To some, it is an unprompted text with a thoughtful date-night itinerary, the day, time and place selected and the reservation made — your only task is to show up. To others, it is an elaborate meal awaiting you at home, labored over by the one you love, to enjoy with a glass of chilled red wine in the seductive glow of scentless taper candles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Ex-Intelligence Official Is Sentenced to 14 Years Over State Secrets
description: Cameron Ortis was convicted of passing state secrets to men under police investigation, but his motives remain unknown. He said it was all part of an international mission he could not disclose.
content: A former civilian director of an elite intelligence unit in the Royal Canadian Mounted Police was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Wednesday after his conviction last year of giving confidential operational information to four men who were targets of police investigations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Ruling for Trump on Eligibility Could Doom His Bid for Immunity
description: As the Supreme Court tries to recapture its authority and legitimacy, it may be tempted to issue a pair of lopsided decisions both for and against the former president.
content: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and his colleagues seemed ready on Thursday to start to rebuild the court’s reputation by presenting themselves as unified and apolitical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Worries About Losing Its Biggest Weapon: U.S. Military Aid
description: Without it, Kyiv could hold out for part of the year, one expert said, but would then begin losing the war.
content: In the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion, Ukraine has had its back to the wall many times, in many forms: fighting with Molotov cocktails and guns handed out to the population, coping with blackouts and fleeing refugees. But there was always the prospect of more American aid on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: No Trial for Biden Over Documents, but a Political Mess
description: Also, the Supreme Court looked poised to reject efforts to kick Trump off ballots. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The special counsel investigating President Biden’s handling of classified material after leaving the vice presidency in 2017 concluded in a report released today that “no criminal charges are warranted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Start to Fix
description: Samuel A. Donaldson returns with some advice for people trying to date.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘They Called Him Mostly Harmless’ Review: Digital Sleuthing
description: In this schematic Max true-crime documentary, amateur detectives take the lead in the quest to identify the body of a male hiker.
content: In 2018, an emaciated male body was found in the Florida wilderness. Blood work showed that he was healthy, with no drugs in his system beyond Tylenol. Among his belongings were food and money, but no phone. The man had been hiking the Appalachian Trail. Several hikers recalled encountering him within the eight months before his death — he was handsome — but they knew him only by his trail name, Mostly Harmless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Patrick F. Smith
title: Toby Keith Was an Enigma Wrapped in a Riddle Wrapped in the Flag
description: He’s best known for a red-state anthem. But Toby Keith existed in a tradition of country rabble-rousers of all political stripes.
content: Toby Keith already had a string of country hits before he wrote the 2002 song that cemented his place in the then-burgeoning culture wars: “Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue (The Angry American).” He later said the song was written in 20 minutes as an emotional response to both his father’s death and the Sept. 11th attacks. When Mr. Keith played it for the first time in a solo performance (his band hadn’t yet learned the chord changes) at the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., the response was rapturous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: ‘Zombie Offices’ Spell Trouble for Some Banks
description: Bank tremors serve as a reminder: Just because a crisis hasn’t hit immediately doesn’t mean commercial real estate pain isn’t coming.
content: Graceful Art Deco buildings towering above Chicago’s key business district report occupancy rates as low as 17 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Matt Stevens
title: All the Times That People Have Hyperventilated About Taylor and Travis
description: The planet’s biggest pop star met America’s biggest sport, and heads collectively exploded. Here are the moments people got happy, sad, angry or annoyed.
content: Way back in July, Travis Kelce, the Kansas City Chiefs’ star tight end, publicly offered himself as a potential suitor for Taylor Swift, whose Eras Tour had catapulted her beyond her already stratospheric fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulo Pinheiro, Hanny Megally and Lynn Welchman
title: Under Gaza’s Shadow, Syria Faces a New Welter of Conflict
description: Fighting has surged on five fronts, bringing more misery to Syria’s people.
content: The scale and ferocity of the conflict in Gaza and the unspeakable suffering of its civilians have rightly provoked the world’s outrage. But in Syria, a steep escalation of violence that has forced the flight of tens of thousands more people in what remains the world’s largest displacement crisis is taking place largely unnoticed outside the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Usher Arrived at the Super Bowl Halftime Show
description: A conversation about his long career path through several generations of R&B, and what he might do on such a big stage.
content: In a 30-year career, Usher has been many things — an R&B prodigy, a history-minded technician, a legitimate crossover pop star, an EDM experimenter and lately, a consummate showman with a Las Vegas residency that prompted untold viral videos of a performer extraordinarily at ease with his gifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Supreme Court Ballot Case Made for Must-Hear TV
description: The live arguments gave audiences a rare chance to experience a Trump court case as it happened.
content: If you were to list the ingredients of riveting live television, you would probably not include still photos, empty TV studios and parsing the nuances between the nouns “office” and “officer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Rebecca Smeyne
title: What Makes a Good Party? A Certain Je Ne Sais Quoi.
description: A new Midtown Manhattan outpost of Silencio, a Parisian nightclub, filled its smoky room with some of the art world’s biggest names.
content: On Wednesday night, two sturdy bouncers framed an unmarked doorway between a pizzeria and a vape shop on West 57th Street. Those granted entry descended a narrow staircase to the door of Silencio New York, where a new offshoot of the swank Parisian nightclub was hosting its inaugural party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Biden Aides Visit Arab American Leaders in Michigan as Pressure Rises Over Gaza
description: White House officials traveled to Dearborn to meet with Arab American leaders as the president faces mounting frustration within his party over his refusal to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.
content: White House officials traveled on Thursday to Dearborn, Mich., to meet with Arab American leaders about the war in Gaza and concerns about Islamophobia at home, as President Biden faces mounting Democratic discontent over his refusal to call for a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen and Yan Zhuang
title: Mojo Nixon, Who Mixed Roots and Punk Rock, Dies at 66
description: A self-described voice of “the doomed, the damned, the weird,” he was known for satirical songs like “Elvis Is Everywhere” and “Destroy All Lawyers.”
content: Mojo Nixon, the singer, songwriter and radio host who rocketed from the lunatic fringe of 1980s underground music to national attention with his rabble-rousing shots at celebrity culture like the 1987 hit “Elvis Is Everywhere” and snarky social commentary like the 1986 song “I Hate Banks,” died on Wednesday aboard a country music cruise. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: He Had Severe Heartburn. Could His Trouble With Balance Be Related?
description: His mouth always tasted like metal and he vomited several times a week. Nothing seemed to help. Then his sister got him the help he needed.
content: “We were thinking about going bowling with the kids tomorrow,” the woman told her 43-year-old brother as they settled into their accustomed spots in the living room of their mother’s home in Chicago. It was late — nearly midnight — and he had arrived from Michigan to spend the days between Christmas and New Year’s with this part of his family. She and her husband and her brother grew up together and spent many late nights laughing and talking. She knew her brother was passionate about bowling. He had spent almost every day in his local alley two summers ago. So she was taken by surprise when he answered, “I can’t do that anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Some on the Right Flirt With a Voting Method the Left Loves
description: Ranked-choice voting could be on the November ballot in four states, a sign of the system’s rising popularity. Most conservatives have opposed it. But some say that could be changing.
content: Long viewed as an intriguing, if somewhat wonky, approach to conducting elections, ranked-choice voting — allowing voters to list candidates in order of preference instead of selecting just one — appears to be having a moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Egill Bjarnason and Emma Bubola
title: Iceland Volcano Erupts Again, Cutting Off Hot Water to Thousands
description: The flowing lava poured over a key pipe that transports hot water from the local power plant to nearby towns.
content: A volcano system in southwestern Iceland erupted on Thursday for the third time since December, spewing out a stream of bright orange lava that cut off a source of heating and hot water for tens of thousands of residents amid freezing temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 8, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 8, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about New York public housing employees charged in a corruption case misidentified the New York City Housing Authority entities affected by the bribery scheme. It was 100 housing developments, not 100 buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: After Years of Decline, Premature Births Rose in the U.S.
description: The reason behind the rise isn’t clear, but experts say maternal health may offer some clues.
content: Premature births, after years of steady decline, rose sharply in the U.S. between 2014 and 2022, according to recently published data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Experts said the shift might be partly the result of a growing prevalence of health complications among mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Netanyahu says Israeli forces will soon enter Rafah.
description: Israel’s prime minister said the military would soon go into to an area of Gaza near the border with Egypt where hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians have fled, something the United Nations has said would be catastrophic.
content: Israel’s prime minister said the military would soon go into to an area of Gaza near the border with Egypt where hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians have fled, something the United Nations has said would be catastrophic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris and Jan Ransom
title: Audit Finds Fatal Lapses in Mental Health Program Meant to Curb Violence
description: The program, known as Kendra’s Law, has sometimes been mired by shoddy oversight and bureaucratic delays, an audit by the state comptroller found.
content: Poor oversight and bureaucratic delays in New York State’s gold-standard program for treating mentally ill people at risk of becoming violent has led in recent years to preventable injuries and even deaths, according to a state audit made public on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Lisa Frankenstein’ Review: When Mom Finds Out, You’re So Dead
description: A little too enamored of its own references, this teen horror-comedy feels a bit misshapen but still delivers some light fun.
content: Ever since Mary Shelley wrote “Frankenstein” at age 19, it has functioned as a remarkably versatile Rorschach test, prescient in ways its author could hardly have anticipated. Usually it’s interpreted as a story about hubris, about man playing God and reaping the consequences. But you can just as easily read it as a lucid explication of Rousseau’s ideas about human nature, or as a slippery narrative told by a not-quite-reliable narrator who’s trying to get away with murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Raven Chacon’s Sound-and-Art Symphony
description: At the Swiss Institute, a Pulitzer-Prize winner makes art warmed — socially and spiritually — by hope.
content: A single work of art can get into your system and stay there. I’ve been living with — haunted by — one by the Navajo composer and sound artist Raven Chacon since encountering it in the 2022 Whitney Biennial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Strong Earnings, and Taylor Swift, Add to Disney’s Defenses
description: The media giant beat analysts’ profit forecasts and announced a slew of new content. Will that be enough to fend off the activist investor Nelson Peltz?
content: Shares in Disney are up more than 7 percent in premarket trading on Thursday, after the entertainment giant released blockbuster quarterly earnings and made a string of headline-grabbing announcements. (Taylor Swift! Fortnite! A “Moana” sequel!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Ennio’ Review: Morricone and His Mastery of Film Scores
description: A lively, absorbing documentary about the Italian composer whose music is featured in hundreds of movies, from “A Fistful of Dollars” to “Kill Bill.”
content: “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,” “Days of Heaven,” “Before the Revolution,” “1900,” “The Untouchables,” “Kill Bill,” “Django Unchained,” “The Mission,” “The Thing,” “Fists in the Pocket,” “The Battle of Algiers,” “The Bird With the Crystal Plumage,” “Bugsy,” “Bulworth,” “Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!” — if you’ve watched a movie in the last half century there’s a good chance that you’ve heard music by Ennio Morricone, the titanic Italian composer and arranger who helped define films as we know and hear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: Seeking a quick solution to longtime homelessness
description: Progress’s challenge: Our problems shape-shift in response to our solutions, which then become problems themselves.
content: In 2008, Alan Graham brought an idea to a neighborhood meeting in Austin, Texas: he wanted to build a mobile home park in the neighborhood for people coming out of chronic homelessness. He already had a plot of land, given to him by the city. But residents hated the idea. They voted against it, 52 to 0. So he shelved it for years until he could reimagine it on the outskirts of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Madeleine Hordinski
title: Her Son Vanished After a 1980 Run-In With Police. She Wants Answers.
description: Investigators in Kentucky have pursued many leads in the search for Randy Sellers, except for what some critics say is the most obvious one.
content: At first, Wanda Cotton searched the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: What to Know About the Race to Replace George Santos
description: The special House election in New York pits Mazi Pilip, a Republican county legislator, against Tom Suozzi, a former Democratic congressman.
content: After nearly a year with George Santos as their local congressman, voters in New York finally have their chance to choose his replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Letter to San Zaw Htway’
description: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased political prisoner wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope. What can we learn from his life and story?
content: Note to teachers: Please note that this week’s film includes powerful and disturbing images — including violence between military forces and protesters. Be sure to review the film before screening with your class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Draeger and Ted Mitchell
title: Every FAFSA Delay Puts College Further Out of Reach
description: Federal financial aid programs were created to open the doors to higher education. FAFSA delays affect those who can least afford to pay for college.
content: Each year, more than 17 million students complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or FAFSA, hoping to secure the financial support they need to afford college. But this year, operational glitches and repeated delays in the U.S. Department of Education’s “Better FAFSA” rollout threaten to harm the very students and families that financial aid is intended to help. Despite promises of an easier, more straightforward application process, students and families so far have been met with glitches and delays, and still today, there are entire groups of students blocked from even completing the form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: You Deserve Something Delicious
description: Such as: gooey-centered chocolate pudding cake, seared scallops with burst tomatoes or velvety Basque cheesecake.
content: We don’t need to tell you that Valentine’s Day is coming up — we trust the cards and candy aisle at your local drugstore has alerted you to that fact. We will, however, remind you that you deserve something delicious and extra special on Feb. 14, whether you’re cooking for yourself, your family or your friends, or (joy of joys) someone is cooking for you. Samantha Seneviratne’s new microwave chocolate pudding cake is a fantastically easy treat. It’s a snap to assemble, cooks with just a push of a button and yields a fudgy, ooey-gooey-centered dessert with crisp, cakey edges. Ice cream, whipped cream or a pour of cold heavy cream are all optional; what you will need is your biggest spoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
title: Pakistan Election Highlights Military’s Sway Over Stormy Politics
description: A crackdown on a major political party and the political resurrection of a former leader are the latest dizzying swerves in the country’s roller-coaster politics.
content: Pakistanis have labeled it a “selection” — not an election. Human rights monitors have condemned it as neither free nor fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: On the Eve of the Super Bowl, Usher Proves His Mastery
description: “Coming Home,” his ninth solo album, cruises through every musical challenge.
content: It has taken perseverance, extraordinary musical gifts and a little luck for Usher to land where he is right now. At 45, the R&B singer and songwriter Usher Raymond is releasing his new album, “Coming Home,” just two days before he will headline the Super Bowl halftime show. In December 2023, he completed an acclaimed 100-show residency in Las Vegas. His single “Good Good,” released last summer, has racked up tens of millions of plays on Spotify. It’s one of the 20 tracks on “Coming Home,” an album that sums up and expands what Usher does best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: 130-Year-Old California Bookstore Seeks Buyer
description: Vroman’s is a community landmark in Pasadena, Calif. Now, its longtime owner says he’s ready to turn over the reins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland and Emily Flitter
title: Big Dreams Come Back to Bite New York Community Bank
description: Acquiring billions of dollars in assets from Signature Bank when it went under last year contributed to the Long Island lender’s troubles.
content: During last spring’s banking crisis, when a competing lender went under, New York Community Bank pounced, acquiring a big chunk of its business. Now, it is paying dearly for that decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Special Counsel Investigating Biden Has Sent Final Report to White House
description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland has also received a copy while the White House reviews it for claims of executive privilege, indicating a public release is nearly at hand.
content: The final report of Robert K. Hur, the special counsel investigating President Biden’s handling of classified documents retained from his vice presidency, has been sent to the White House and to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, two of the final steps before its public release, officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: More Adolescent Boys Have Eating Disorders. Two Experts Discuss Why.
description: For the longest time, researchers focused on diagnosing and treating girls, but that is changing.
content: For decades, eating disorders were thought to afflict mostly, if not exclusively, women and girls. In fact, until 2013, the loss of menstruation had long been considered an official symptom of anorexia nervosa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Special Counsel’s Report Puts Biden’s Age and Memory in the Spotlight
description: After an inquiry concluded that President Biden was “well-meaning” but had “a poor memory,” he angrily fired back in an attempt at political damage control.
content: The decision on Thursday not to file criminal charges against President Biden for mishandling classified documents should have been an unequivocal legal exoneration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Dick Waterman, Promoter and Photographer of the Blues, Dies at 88
description: A “crackpot eccentric Yankee” from Massachusetts, he revived the careers of long-forgotten Southern artists during the blues boom of the 1960s.
content: Dick Waterman, a beacon in the world of blues who as a promoter, talent manager and photographer helped revive the careers of a generation of storied purveyors of that bedrock American art form while lyrically documenting their journeys with his camera, died on Jan. 26 in Oxford, Miss. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Do You Think About ‘Right to Disconnect’ Laws?
description: Share your thoughts with us.
content: In Australia, “out of office” may soon take on a whole new level of importance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Bars Antiwar Candidate in Election Putin Is All But Sure of Winning
description: The barring of the only candidate voicing opposition to the war in Ukraine showed how little tolerance the Kremlin has for dissent. Here’s what to know about the presidential election in March.
content: Russian authorities on Thursday banned from the presidential race the only candidate who had openly contested President Vladimir V. Putin’s hold on power in Russia, and who made his opposition to the war in Ukraine central to his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Try Stand-Up for the First Time
description: Delivering a deluge of hard jokes, this double act aims directly for the nostalgic pleasure centers of their fans.
content: To hear them tell it, the origin story of Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, one of our greatest comedy duos, hinges on a moment in 1994 on tour with Second City in Waco, Texas, when they met an Australian woman wearing a sling who spoke “lovingly” about the return of the dead cult leader David Koresh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The First New Oscar in More Than 20 Years Goes to Casting Directors
description: After decades of lobbying from the casting field, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is adding its first new award category since 2001.
content: The Academy Awards is introducing an Oscar for casting, the ceremony’s governing organization announced Thursday, making it the first new category in more than 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: What to Know About Pakistan’s Election
description: Analysts say Pakistan’s powerful military has never intervened so openly on behalf of its preferred candidate.
content: Pakistan went to the polls on Thursday for an election that analysts say will be among the least credible in the country’s 76-year history, one that comes at a particularly turbulent moment for the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: A New General Takes Over as Ukraine Struggles on the Battlefield
description: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky is taking a job vacated by a general who is well-regarded by the army, in what is widely perceived as a politicized shake-up of Ukraine’s military leadership.
content: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky, who was appointed commander of the Ukrainian military on Thursday, led two successful counteroffensives in the war against Russia before his troops became bogged down in one of the most contentious and costly battles of the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Vikingur Olafsson’s ‘Goldbergs’ Mesmerize Carnegie Hall
description: In his debut on the main Carnegie stage, Olafsson gave a spectacular reading of Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations.
content: On Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, the pianist Vikingur Olafsson’s performance of Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations had everyone in a trance — including him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: How Mark Meadows Became the Least Trusted Man in Washington
description: The untold story of the rise and fall of Trump’s former chief of staff — and his role in the prosecutions that may determine the 2024 election.
content: On most Monday mornings, Mark Meadows commutes from his home in South Carolina to his workplace in Washington. He flies first class and travels light, moving briskly through Reagan airport, sometimes accompanied by his wife, Debbie, or by weekend guests, like his close friend and fellow archconservative Representative Jim Jordan, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. He is then ferried to the Capitol Hill headquarters of the Conservative Partnership Institute, or C.P.I., the nonprofit right-wing hub Meadows joined a week after Donald Trump left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Deflation Alarms Raised by Falling Prices for Food and Cars
description: In addition to consumer price declines in January, wholesale prices fell last month, and have been down in every month since October 2022.
content: Consumer prices fell last month in China by the most since the global financial crisis in 2009, the latest sign that weak spending and a glut of output from factories and farms are forcing businesses to offer discounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Donald Trump’s Man in Nevada
description: Michael McDonald, the chair of the Nevada G.O.P. and a fake elector, said he’d deliver the state’s delegates to Mr. Trump. The party’s caucuses seem set to do so.
content: Before the chairman of Nevada’s Republican Party introduced former President Donald J. Trump at a campaign event last month, he casually referred to a telling private conversation they’d had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Erin Griffith
title: American Firms Invested $1 Billion in Chinese Chips, Lawmakers Find
description: A congressional investigation determined that U.S. funding helped fuel the growth of a sector now viewed by Washington as a security threat.
content: A congressional investigation has determined that five American venture capital firms invested more than $1 billion in China’s semiconductor industry since 2001, fueling the growth of a sector that the United States government now regards as a national security threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Rising Star in Fashion Who Sees No Future in New York
description: Carly Mark, founder of the cultish brand Puppets and Puppets, plans to drastically shift her business and leave the country.
content: On a phone call in October, Carly Mark raised the idea for the first time: She needed to leave New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: The Shaky U.S.-Israel Alliance
description: The war in Gaza is straining the relationship between the two nations.
content: It’s a tough time for the U.S.-Israel alliance. The death toll from the Gaza war has shaken Washington officials. President Biden wants Israel to recognize a Palestinian state, something its current government opposes. Top Israeli officials openly criticize Biden. Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, is just concluding a trip there to seek common ground — his seventh visit to the country since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnatan Reiss
title: Some Hostages’ Families Say Israel Should Keep Fighting Hamas
description: A few relatives of hostages held in Gaza argue that Israel’s military must not be too quick to end the war, even if it prolongs their loved ones’ captivity.
content: As mediators pursue a deal that would free hostages from Gaza in exchange for a pause in Israel’s military campaign, a small group of relatives of Israeli hostages says that the government should keep waging war against Hamas — even if it prolongs their loved ones’ captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Political Perils of a Black-Jewish Rift Over the War in Gaza
description: A divide bodes ill for Democrats — and perhaps even for Palestinians.
content: “There’s no alliance more historic, nor more important, than the alliance between Black Americans and Jewish Americans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: C.D.C. Investigating Gastrointestinal Illness on Luxury Cruise Ship
description: The Queen Victoria was on its way to Honolulu from San Francisco on a 107-night world cruise when more than 150 people on board reported symptoms, officials said.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating an outbreak on a luxury cruise ship after more than 150 people reported symptoms of gastrointestinal illness, including diarrhea and vomiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Michael Mann, a Leading Climate Scientist, Wins His Defamation Suit
description: The researcher had sued two writers for libel and slander over comments about his work. The jury awarded him damages of more than $1 million.
content: The climate scientist Michael Mann on Thursday won his defamation lawsuit against Rand Simberg, a former adjunct scholar at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, and Mark Steyn, a contributor to National Review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Freeman and Lucas Perelló
title: The Drop in Crime in El Salvador Is Stunning, but It Has a Dark Side
description: For all of its success in lowering crime, the Bukele model comes at a stark cost. Copycats beware.
content: Voters in El Salvador this week gave their tough-on-crime president a sweeping mandate: Keep going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Isabella Kwai
title: Australia Introduces Workers’ ‘Right to Disconnect’
description: If the legislation passes, companies could face fines if they penalize employees for failing to respond to work-related communication in off-work hours.
content: When it’s after hours, and the boss is on the line, Australian workers — already among the world’s best-rested and most personally fulfilled employees — can soon press “decline” in favor of the seductive call of the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A Year With One Turkish Family Trying to Heal
description: Times Journalists followed the Karapirli family as they recovered from an earthquake that upended their lives and the lives of many others.
content: When Ben Hubbard, the Istanbul bureau chief for The New York Times, and his colleague Safak Timur arrived in Gaziantep, Turkey, last February, one day after a 7.8-magnitude earthquake shook the area, a flattened six-story apartment building caught their attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: We Americans Neglect Our Children
description: American children are more likely to live in poverty, go hungry and die young than in most of our peer countries. We can fix this.
content: Individually, we adore and pamper our children. We shuttle them from soccer practice to music lessons and then organize their play dates with meticulous fanaticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Get Ready to Dress Up Again
description: And everything else you need to know about the coming fashion season, including designer debuts, mega-shows and gossip.
content: Fashion Month, that four-week extravaganza of shows, celebrities and clothes that has become a perfect vehicle of bite-size entertainment for our attention-fractured time, officially begins in New York on Friday before rolling out to London, Milan and Paris. In reality, however, it started a full week earlier, thanks to Marc Jacobs, who like many designers, stepped off the formal schedule during Covid but, unlike many, never looked back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Monk and the Gun’ Review: A Satirical Fable in a Faraway Land
description: This feature follows two monks in Bhutan, often portrayed as a Shangri-La, as the country readies for its first democratic elections.
content: “The Monk and the Gun,” a modestly scaled, lightly comic and blithely ingratiating tale set in Bhutan takes place in the recent past, when the country held mock elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Patrick Kingsley
title: A Blinken Visit Puts U.S.-Israeli Tensions on Full Display
description: During a round of diplomacy by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seemed to be speaking to a domestic audience that does not want to let up pressure on Hamas.
content: As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sat down with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel this week, American and Arab officials were expressing cautious optimism over the latest proposal from Hamas for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Lynn Levy, Patia Braithwaite and Diane Wong
title: Life Lessons From a Finnish Knitting Star
description: How the YouTube channel “Kutovakika” helped our editor untangle her perfectionism.
content: Well’s senior editor Patia Braithwaite isn’t normally prone to following influencers. But a few years ago, she stumbled on a YouTube channel called “Kutovakika” and immediately fell in love. The channel’s star, Veronika Lindberg, known to her viewers as Kika, is a Finnish knitwear designer whose videos show her knitting everything from elaborately patterned sweaters to her own wedding dress. As a novice knitter herself, Patia appreciates the knitting tutorials, but what she loves most is how Kika helps her let go of her own fierce perfectionism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: The Land of Ferrari and Lamborghini Has a New Speed Limit: 30 K.P.H.
description: Bologna has become the first major Italian city to impose the limit on most streets, citing safety and livability. But it’s too slow for some: “A city has to move,” one cabby complained.
content: When Bologna became the first major Italian city to impose a speed limit of 30 kilometers, or 20 miles, an hour, Luca Mazzoli, a local taxi driver, posted a sign in his cab warning passengers of the change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: UEFA Eases Term Limits but President Says He Won’t Test Them
description: Aleksander Ceferin prevailed in an effort that would have allowed him another four-year stint as president. Then he announced he wouldn’t seek one.
content: European soccer leaders on Thursday fell squarely in line behind their powerful president, Aleksander Ceferin, by approving a change to term-limit rules that would have allowed him to retain his post through 2031, years beyond the organization’s strict 12-year term limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Google Releases Gemini, an A.I.-Driven Chatbot and Voice Assistant
description: As it races to compete with OpenAI’s ChatGPT, Google has retired its Bard chatbot and released a more powerful app.
content: First, there were talking digital assistants like Siri, Alexa and Google Assistant. Then there were online chatbots like ChatGPT and Google Bard. Now, the two are merging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Si Spiegel, War Hero Who Modernized Christmas Trees, Dies at 99
description: The son of Jewish immigrants, he was a pilot in World War II who later created patents to mass-produce artificial conifers.
content: Before he became known as the father of artificial Christmas trees, Si Spiegel was a valiant Army aviator. In the closing days of World War II, he was piloting his B-17 Flying Fortress in an armada of 1,500 Allied bombers that pummeled Berlin. Struck by antiaircraft flak, two of the plane’s four engines lost power as Mr. Spiegel reversed course to return to England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: No, ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ Is Not ‘the Worst’
description: A defense of Gershwin’s masterpiece on the occasion of its centennial.
content: A couple of weeks ago in The Times, a seasoned musician and composer proposed that George Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” was “corny and Caucasian,” a “cheesecake” that has “clogged the arteries of American music.” And this in the centennial year of the rhapsody, which was first played on Feb. 12, 1924, at Aeolian Hall in Manhattan! Anyone making such a charge should expect a bit of pushback. Herewith some.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Winners of Our Ninth Annual Student Review Contest
description: Read critical commentary by teenagers on Olivia Rodrigo, “Succession,” a state flag, a trendy pink tumbler and more.
content: If you’re looking for something new to read, watch, play, listen to, wear, eat or visit, look no further. Below, we present the finalists of our Ninth Annual Student Review Contest, in which we invited teenagers to play critic and submit original reviews about any kind of creative expression covered in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Splitting the Rent Saves Couples the Most Money
description: A study looked at the cost-savings of moving in together.
content: Is love transactional? When it comes to moving in together and splitting the rent, yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: David Soukup, Advocate for Abused and Neglected Children, Dies at 90
description: While serving as a judge in Seattle, he was inspired to start an organization to help children who did not have unbiased advocates in court proceedings.
content: David W. Soukup was a judge in Seattle when he was faced with an unnerving decision. A 3-year-old girl had been taken to a city hospital with injuries that a doctor found consistent with abuse. In court, the mother insisted her daughter had merely fallen off a swing — and anyway, she said, her boyfriend had moved out and wasn’t coming back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Five Marines Died in Helicopter Crash in California, Military Says
description: The Marines were on a training flight in a CH-53E Super Stallion helicopter that went missing east of San Diego on Tuesday.
content: The Marine Corps confirmed on Thursday that five Marines had died in Tuesday’s helicopter crash east of San Diego.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
title: Zelensky Removes His Top General, in Major Shake-Up of Ukraine Military
description: Gen. Valery Zaluzhny led the effort that thwarted Russia’s initial assault on Kyiv. But his troops have struggled to make progress recently, and tensions have mounted with the civilian leadership.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday removed his top general as part of a sweeping overhaul of his military command, the most significant shake-up in Ukrainian leadership since Russia invaded almost two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump, Putin, Carlson and the Shifting Sands of Today’s American Politics
description: An interview with Russia’s leader and congressional resistance to aid for Ukraine underscore the transformation of the parties and electorate in the United States more than three decades after the Cold War.
content: The idea was to isolate him, to make him a pariah, to put him in a box as punishment for brazen violations of international law. They kicked him out of their world leaders’ clubhouse, cut off his country’s economy, even issued an arrest warrant against him for war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Report Calls for Putin and Others to Be Investigated for Assault on Mariupol
description: Human rights groups said the attack on the Ukrainian port city pointed to unlawful actions by top Russian leaders.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials should be investigated for war crimes after the destruction in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol killed thousands of civilians, Human Rights Watch and several other organizations said Thursday at the end of a two-year investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: What’s in a Name? RuNyx Won’t Tell You.
description: The author of “Gothikana” isn’t going to reveal much. But she will share a useful tip for writing and life.
content: “I had a stalker when I was in college, so that turned me off to the idea of putting everything out there,” RuNyx said in a video interview. It was her 30th birthday, and she was on her third day of a hotel room quarantine after a wedding weekend in a distant country. But Covid wasn’t the reason her camera was off: RuNyx, whose best-selling romance novel, “Gothikana,” is the toast of TikTok, prefers to remain anonymous. In fact, she insists on it. Assiduously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Families Are Split: 49ers or Taylor Swift?
description: The Super Bowl is bringing to the surface an amusing but very real generational divide in the Bay Area.
content: Squabbles between parents and children are as old as time, but a new divide has sprung up among some families in San Francisco — and it’s a big one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: These Soccer Players’ Not-So-Secret Weapon: Lêkê
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 8, 2024.
content: “Apart from in the office, you can wear them everywhere, even at a party.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Migrant Crisis Complicates Democrats’ Bid to Regain George Santos’s Seat
description: The party has turned to a moderate veteran, Tom Suozzi, to restore its tarnished brand. But the migrant influx reaching New York has complicated his task.
content: Just two months ago, George Santos’s expulsion from the House looked like everything Democrats could have asked for. It gave them an open Republican seat in a winnable New York district, with an electorate still reeling from the congressman’s spectacular unraveling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 14, 2024
description: What do brides in opposite-sex marriages do with their last names?
content: This graph was previously published in The New York Times. The data is from the April 2023 poll by The Pew Research Center, a nonpartisan “fact tank” that conducts surveys and produces reports on issues, attitudes and trends shaping the world. The poll includes a nationally representative panel of 2,740 currently married American women in opposite-sex marriages. There were not enough Asian American women in the sample to analyze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
title: In ‘The New Look,’ It’s Chanel Versus Dior in War-Torn Paris
description: Juliette Binoche and Ben Mendelsohn play the two fashion icons during the Nazi occupation of France in a new series from Apple TV+.
content: In “The New Look,” an Apple TV+ show premiering Feb. 14, wine glasses are never empty, cigarettes are always half-smoked and everyone is thin. The series follows two titans of French fashion, Christian Dior and Coco Chanel, after all, toward the end of World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Please Let It Not Be a Woman
description: If Donald Trump chooses a woman to be his running mate, it would send an insidious message.
content: Whoever Donald Trump chooses as his running mate, please let it not be a woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Riad al-Turk, the ‘Mandela of Syria,’ Dies in Exile at 93
description: Imprisoned four times, he spent almost 20 years in Syria’s prisons, nearly 18 in solitary confinement, for speaking out against the Assad regimes. He died in France.
content: Riad al-Turk, a veteran Syrian opposition leader known as the “Mandela of Syria” after spending nearly two decades in prison for speaking out against his country’s dictatorial regimes, died on Jan. 1 in Eaubonne, a northern suburb of Paris. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Jonathan Majors Had a History of Abuse in Relationships, Women Say
description: The actor denied physical abuse. Separately, he said he wasn’t told of accusations of misbehavior on the set of “Lovecraft Country.”
content: Since the actor Jonathan Majors was found guilty in December of assaulting and harassing a girlfriend, he has maintained his innocence and his hope of reviving a once-skyrocketing career that disintegrated in the wake of his conviction. In a televised interview last month, he said that he had “never struck a woman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Here’ Review: A Celebration of Connection
description: In Bas Devos’s muted and luminous Belgian drama, two lonely souls repeatedly encounter each other.
content: One-word titles like that of the Belgian writer and director Bas Devos’s “Here” can create a minuet of meaning. In this hushed drama that gently rebuffs the beats of a love story even as it hints at one, the word is a call for the viewer’s attention and an acknowledgment of place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Walter Shawlee, the Sovereign of Slide Rules, Is Dead at 73
description: Used by engineers for centuries, they were displaced by pocket calculators and all but forgotten until Mr. Shawlee created a subculture of obsessives and cornered the market.
content: For about 350 years, humanity’s most innovative hand-held computer was something called a slide rule. As typewriters once symbolized the writer, slide rules symbolized the engineer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Marc Santora
title: Ukraine’s Creative Use of Weapons Carries Promise and Risk
description: A Russian plane shot down with a Patriot missile was probably carrying Ukrainian prisoners of war, U.S. officials say.
content: U.S. officials say Ukraine should continue to develop innovative ways to strike at Russian forces as the war approaches its third year. But Ukraine’s use of a Patriot missile to take down a plane last month is an example of how novel battlefield tactics can be fraught with peril as well as promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Latino Organizers Say Republicans Took a Risk in Ignoring Nevada
description: G.O.P. presidential candidates bypassed the state because of a complicated, noncompetitive primary process. It also may have deterred some Latino voters.
content: Four years ago, East Las Vegas, Nev., was a hub for presidential candidates engaging in heavy retail politicking. This year, it was anything but.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Mayorkas Says He’s ‘Focused on the Work’ After Impeachment Fails
description: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, has learned to keep his head down through the drama, his confidants say
content: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, did not take time for a victory lap after surviving a chaotic impeachment vote in the House this week. He hopped a flight to Las Vegas, where he outlined security preparations for the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Struggle to Treat Mentally Ill People on the Street
description: An audit found that the city doesn’t really know if a program to treat severely mentally ill people is working. Many don’t take their medications.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at a program to treat severely mentally ill people on the streets — and why an audit says the city is not doing enough to see that it is getting results. We will also find out why 16- and 17-year-olds in Newark will not get to vote as soon as they had hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Monarch Butterfly Numbers Are Down Sharply at Wintering Areas in Mexico
description: Scientists said the decline appeared to be driven by hot, dry conditions in the United States and Canada that reduced food supply.
content: The number of monarch butterflies at their overwintering areas in Mexico dropped precipitously this year to the second-lowest level on record, according to an annual survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Have We Crossed a Dangerous Warming Threshold? Here’s What to Know.
description: Recent temperature rises have come uncomfortably close to a key benchmark: 1.5 degrees Celsius. It’s a bad sign for the world’s climate goals, but it’s not game over. Not yet.
content: Our planet’s hottest January on record also helped global warming pass a different, unwelcome milestone, according to data released on Thursday by the European Union climate monitor: Over the past 12 months, the average temperature worldwide was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, higher than it was at the dawn of the industrial age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: Seeking a Family, They Got More Than They Bargained For
description: After multiple cycles of I.V.F. and donor eggs, doctors told Andres and Karen Castaño — who married in 2019 — that they would be having triplets.
content: When Andres and Karen Castaño’s relationship turned serious in June 2018, there was only one issue that worried Mr. Castaño. He wanted children badly. But he wasn’t sure if Ms. Castaño did, or even could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Bark of Millions’ Review: Children of the Revolution
description: If Taylor Mac and Matt Ray’s four-hour rock opera were aiming to succeed on aural gorgeousness and visual spectacle alone, there would be no cause to quibble.
content: Somewhere close to the four-hour mark in “Bark of Millions,” the polychromatic cavalcade of splendor that is Taylor Mac and Matt Ray’s new rock opera, I finally realized why the woman in front of me had been reading on her phone throughout the performance. And why she had looked at me like I was way out of line when I couldn’t bear the glowing screen any longer, leaned forward and implored her to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael Levenson
title: Netanyahu Spurns Hamas Offer for Gaza Cease-Fire
description: The Israeli prime minister said that the proposed deal would leave Israel vulnerable to attack and that its forces were preparing to expand their operations.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, dashing hopes that a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip might be close, on Wednesday spurned a proposal from Hamas and said that Israel had directed its forces to prepare to operate in a Gazan city that has become a refuge for more than one million Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Race Is On to Stop Ozempic Muscle Loss
description: Gym chains, nutrition startups and drugmakers all want to solve a common issue among people who take weight loss drugs.
content: As drugs like Ozempic become increasingly popular for weight loss, more doctors and patients are looking for ways to counteract the muscle loss that can happen on these medications — and companies are racing to meet that demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: There’s No Limit to What the Negroni Can Do
description: Play with its simple formula, and you can make a number of delicious, bittersweet cocktails.
content: The Negroni, a strong Italian-born classic with a huge and committed fan club, fits every season and most occasions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: What Happens Next in Trump’s Supreme Court Case on His Eligibility
description: The justices put the case on a fast track when they agreed to hear it, and the parties have asked for a quick decision.
content: It usually takes the Supreme Court about three months after an argument to issue a decision. The biggest rulings tend not to arrive until late June, no matter how early in the term the cases were argued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Thursday Briefing
description: A U.S. strike kills a militia commander in Iraq.
content: A U.S. Special Operations drone strike in Baghdad killed a senior leader of Kata’ib Hezbollah, a militia that U.S. officials blame for recent attacks against American personnel, the Pentagon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Alphabet City, the Flatiron district and Jackson Heights.
content: A two-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 900-square-foot co-op duplex with an open floor plan, a windowed kitchen with a vented range and a washer/dryer on the first level; two bedrooms and a full bath on the second level; and mini-split heating and air-conditioning throughout, on the top floor of a six-story walk-up with a part-time super, a garden and a roof deck. Lucy Wu, BOND New York, 917-678-1348; bondnewyork.com
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Upper East Side Is for Restaurant Lovers
description: In my first dispatch since returning from my stint on The Times’s Live team, I shared a laundry list of exciting developments in the restaurant world, including that Regina’s Grocery & Deli, a beloved Lower East Side staple, had opened a third location on the Upper East Side. (Over Instagram messages, the owner, Roman Grandinetti, told me he chose the area over so many others because it felt like “a real neighborhood.”)
content: In my first dispatch since returning from my stint on The Times’s Live team, I shared a laundry list of exciting developments in the restaurant world, including that Regina’s Grocery & Deli, a beloved Lower East Side staple, had opened a third location on the Upper East Side. (Over Instagram messages, the owner, Roman Grandinetti, told me he chose the area over so many others because it felt like “a real neighborhood.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Cleared in Documents Case; Report Raises Concerns About His Memory
description: The inquiry found that the president had willfully retained material after finishing his term as vice president and had shared sensitive information with a ghostwriter.
content: The special counsel investigating President Biden said in a report released on Thursday that Mr. Biden had “willfully” retained and disclosed classified material after leaving the vice presidency in 2017 but concluded that “no criminal charges are warranted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: You’re ‘Solo Poly’? So … You’re Single?
description: Not quite, according to practitioners, who want people to understand that the lifestyle is more than a dressed-up “friends with benefits.”
content: After James Nicholson went through a breakup in October, he realized that he was at a point in his life when he wanted to focus more on himself than on someone else, but without losing the perks of romantic intimacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: A Good Day for Trump and His Lawyers
description: The Supreme Court justices expressed doubts about barring Trump.
content: The Supreme Court seems ready to hand Donald Trump his first consequential legal victory of the campaign season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Some Colleges Are Pivoting as FAFSA Delays Drag On
description: The state schools in California and many other colleges are extending their May 1 commitment deadlines. Some are also creating new aid forms.
content: The University of California and California State University systems on Wednesday became the latest of a growing list of schools to give applicants extensions on their intent to register, now that colleges won’t get federal financial aid data until at least March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Who Drugged Wife’s Drinks to Cause Abortion Gets 180 Days in Jail
description: Mason Herring, 39, of Houston, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to injury of a child and assault of a pregnant woman.
content: A Texas man who drugged his wife’s drinks in an unsuccessful attempt to induce an abortion was sentenced on Wednesday to 180 days in jail and 10 years of probation, the Harris County district clerk’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Falling Into a Hole
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Lover, Stalker, Killer’ Review: True Crime With Lots of Twists
description: This documentary directed by Sam Hobkinson focuses on a jump back into the dating pool that soon turns horrific.
content: True-crime doc watchers who are in committed relationships may see “Lover, Stalker, Killer,” a bracing account of a lurid series of misdeeds directed by Sam Hobkinson, and breathe a sigh of relief over being out of the dating pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Where’s Merce? He’s in the Purse. (His Ashes, That Is.)
description: The current season of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” meets Merce Cunningham in an incongruous mash-up of reality TV and modern dance.
content: “Can you get my drink, and I’ll get Merce?“
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Stanley Cups, Distracted Walking and Taylor Swift: Teens React to the News
description: We invited teenagers to weigh in on three recent articles via our Picture Prompts column.
content: What is your reaction to the hype around Stanley cups? Is walking while looking at your phone a problem? And are TV broadcasts giving too much attention to Taylor Swift at N.F.L. games?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Google Joins Effort to Help Spot Content Made With A.I.
description: The tech company’s plan is similar to one announced two days earlier by Meta, another Silicon Valley giant.
content: Google, whose work in artificial intelligence helped make A.I.-generated content far easier to create and spread, now wants to ensure that such content is traceable as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Polluted Flowers Smell Less Sweet to Pollinators, Study Finds
description: The research, involving primroses and hawk moths, suggests that air pollution could be interfering with plant reproduction.
content: The damage that air pollution can do is wide-ranging and well-known: The chemicals produced by human activities can trap heat in the atmosphere, change the chemistry of the oceans and harm human health in myriad ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage

description: From a reimagined centuries-old palazzo to a private apartment with a rooftop terrace, five new places to stay that offer a fresh vision of the city.
content: While Rome’s charms may be, as they say, eternal, it’s never been a city particularly prized for its hotels. Until recently, upmarket lodging in the Italian capital usually meant an ostentatiously decorated pile meant to evoke the city’s 16th- and 17th-century palazzi, stuffed with gilded furniture and vague nostalgia. Over the past year or so, an entirely new breed of luxury hotel has emerged, one that pays tribute to the modernist architects who remade much of Rome in the Rationalist style in the early-to-mid-20th century. The Bulgari hotel, for example, opened last summer in a hulking 1930s government building designed by the prominent Trieste-born architect Vittorio Ballio Morpurgo. And the Edition hotel moved into a bank partly attributed to Marcello Piacentini, the architect responsible for the EUR district, the neighborhood of massive edifices constructed under Mussolini. Other notable new offerings take their style cues from 21st-century Scandinavia, deftly blending northern design aesthetics with Italian Renaissance art and Roman artifacts.
